value: <add xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" place="margin">76</add>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">She is taken home secretly by her father. Her mother</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">cries <quote source="#" rend="inline">"when a fresh [untaught?] is an [hoor?] "If it</quote></l>

<quote xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" source="#" rend="inline">
            <l>had pleased God when I did hear her that she &</l>
            <l>I had been buried it had saved me from a</l>
            <l>great deal of sorrow & grief & her <del>..</del> from ....</l>
            <l>such shame as never had Cheshire woman, ....</l>
            <l>Write no more to me of her"</l>
          </quote>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>But save for their sf</del> But the drama</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>of the</del> <del>abandoned girl</del> moves in darkness.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>She moves through the court without speaking</del></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>seen <del>by an</del> only by a</del> She is solicited by <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-wkno" key="Knollys, Sir William">Knollys</rs>;</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">seduced by <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-wpem" key="Pembroke, William (Lord)">Pembroke</rs> <del>without</del> <del>[dressed?]</del> up as a man</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>without opening her lips. We see her in the white</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">cloak only through the eyes of one Mrs [Maeken?]</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">who dwelt at the <rs type="place" ref="../resources/annotations.xml/pla-chop" key="Chopping Knife">Chopping Knife</rs> near</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Ludgate". And her single letter to her sister,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">only speaks ceremoniously of the passing of time.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>So</del> <del>She</del> <del>The letters are all</del> <del>The common speech</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Facts, <del>writing</del> She</l>
<add xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" place="margin">127.</add>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Her own [passes?], the disgrace, the humiliation of the family</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">are all hidden under <del>the</del> flourishes & ornament,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">parables & similes. <del><rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-espe" key="Spenser, Edmund">Spenser</rs> is quoted</del>.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Spring & summer: the frost that [illeg.] affection; the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">flower of a garden – the <del>kn</del> <del>semblance</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>naturally</del> her, levity & laughter in their old</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">metaphor; though the meaning – that the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">man is in love with the girl & wishes to</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">[breed?] from her <del>breaks</del> here & again</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Spenser is quoted. Indeed, the poets</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">have <del>taken from the pen</del> have made it</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">impossible for simple squires & country</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">ladies to write English And behind their</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">florid decoration, their strained elegance,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the men & women are [fallible?], crude,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">[barbal?]; seducing each other; the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">wolves & foxes of the court pray & raven.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>Only we</del> The bastards are born. Reflections</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">are [illeg.] [Why?] what</l>
